SENT.plain: Red meat and processed meat intake is associated with a risk of colorectal cancer, a major cause of death in affluent countries
Epidemiological and experimental evidence supports the hypothesis that heme iron present in meat promotes colorectal cancer
This meta-analysis of prospective cohort studies of colon cancer reporting heme intake included 566,607 individuals and 4,734 cases of colon cancer
The relative risk of colon cancer was 1.18 (95% CI: 1.06-1.32) for subjects in the highest category of heme iron intake compared with those in the lowest category
Epidemiological data thus show a suggestive association between dietary heme and risk of colon cancer
The analysis of experimental studies in rats with chemically-induced colon cancer showed that dietary hemoglobin and red meat consistently promote aberrant crypt foci, a putative precancer lesion

The mechanism is not known, but heme iron has a catalytic effect on (i) the endogenous formation of carcinogenic N-nitroso compounds and (ii) the formation of cytotoxic and genotoxic aldehydes by lipoperoxidation
A review of evidence supporting these hypotheses suggests that both pathways are involved in heme iron toxicity
